title: Towergate settles poaching case over its new top team

Wed, Aug 26, 2015, 11:35 BST - UK Markets close in 4 hrs 55 mins Towergate settles poaching case over its new top team By Marion Dakers | Telegraph – 15 minutes ago Print 
Loss-making insurance broker is hiring five executives from rival firm Gallagher 
Towergate and its new owners are bringing in a new executive team earlier than expected, after agreeing to pay £20m to settle a poaching complaint from rival insurance broker Gallagher. 
Towergate, which was rescued by its lenders earlier this year to restructure its £1bn debt pile, said David Ross will join as chief executive in November, following four of his senior colleagues at Gallagher into the firm. 
The firm has been fighting legal action following the hiring spree shortly after its rescue in February. Gallagher launched High Court action against Towergate in March, claiming that the exodus had jeopardised attempts to take over its struggling rival. 
The executives denied the claim, with Mr Ross claiming that he was put under surveillance after announcing his resignation . 
“As part of the settlement, Gallagher has agreed to the early release of David Ross, effective 1 November 2015, and Adrian Brown and Sarah Dalgarno, effective 2 September 2015. The parties will not be providing further details on these matters,” said Gallagher in a statement. 
Chief financial officer Mark Mugge and retail broking director Janice Deakin have already joined the firm. 
Towergate has agreed to pay £4m this month and £4m in April 2016 to end all litigation. Highbridge, which led the group of unsecured creditors that took over the firm, will foot the rest of the £20m bill. 
Towergate’s interim chief executive, Scott Egan, is leaving next month to become finance director at RSA. His move was announced before RSA became the subject of takeover interest from Zurich. 
Meanwhile, the firm reported a pre-tax loss of £58m for the first six months of the year, as the new team works to stabilise the business following the rescue. Income fell 10pc to £184m, while expenses rose from 68pc to 79pc of income. 
The company said the second quarter of the year had brought slower customer losses and improved new business sales. Towergate, built into a multi-billion pound business by acquiring hundreds of smaller insurance brokers, has been selling off some of its assets as part of the restructuring. 
“I am encouraged by the more recent small improvements in some of our key performance measures and look forward to working with the leadership team in tackling the challenges and opportunities which lie ahead,” said chairman John Tiner.
